{{Infobox NFL_season | team = Tampa Bay Buccaneers | year = 2011 | record = 4-8 | division_place = 4th [[NFC South]] | coach = [[Raheem Morris]] | owner = [[Malcolm Glazer]] | general manager = [[Mark Dominik]] | stadium = [[Raymond James Stadium]] | playoffs = TBD | uniform = | pro bowlers = TBD | AP All-pros = | MVP = | ROY = }} The '''[[2011 NFL season|2011]] [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] season''' will be the club's 36th season as a franchise in the [[National Football League|NFL]]. The team will compete in the [[NFC South]]. Both of their [[National Football League preseason|preseason]] home games, and seven of their [[National Football League regular season|regular season]] home games will be played at [[Raymond James Stadium]] in [[Tampa, Florida]]. One regular season home game, on October 23, was played at [[Wembley Stadium]] in [[London]] as part of the [[NFL International Series]]{{cite news | title=Lockout Could Jeopardize Game Set for London | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/19/sports/football/19sportsbriefs-LOCKOUTCOULD_BRF.html | publisher=The New York Times | first=Judy | last=Battista | date=2011-04-18 accessdate=2011-04-18}} [[Raheem Morris]] will spend his third season as head coach. The team will attempt to make the playoffs for the first time since [[2007 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|2007]]. The team will try to build upon their success from [[2010 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|2010]], when despite having a 10-6 record, they failed to make the playoffs. By week 12, however, the lost their seventh game of the season, preventing them from matching their 2010 record. {{TOClimit|3}} ==Offseason== ===2011 draft board=== {{Main|2011 NFL Draft}} After finishing the 2010 season 10-6 and narrowly missing the playoffs, the Buccaneers had the 20th overall pick in the 2011 NFL Draft. A provision in the now expired collective bargaining agreement ensured that the draft still take place, despite the current lockout and lack of a new CBA. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! Johnson]] (Min) *[[Scott Albritton]] *[[Ross Homan]] *[[Will Barker]] (Mia) *[[Allen Bradford (American football)|Allen Bradford]] (Sea) {{col-end}} ===Practice Squad=== {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-4}} *[[Chris Riley (American football)|Chris Riley]] *[[Ahmad Black]] *[[Rudy Carpenter]] *[[Collin Franklin]] {{col-2-of-4}} *[[Ed Gant]] *[[Nic Grinsby]] *[[Swanson Miller]] *[[Matt Clapp]] {{col-end}} ===Injuries/reserve lists=== *[[Andrew Economos]] was placed on the PUP list (Sept. 3); he was re-activated November 4. *[[Cody Grimm]] suffered damage to the [[Medial collateral ligament|MCL]] in his right knee (week 3){{cite news |url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/football/bucs/tampa-bay-buccaneers-safety-cody-grimm-likely-out-for-season/1193710 |title=Tampa Bay Buccaneers safety Cody Grimm likely out for season |publisher=TBO.com |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |first=Rick |last=Stroud |date=2011-09-26 |accessdate=2011-09-26}} and was placed on injured reserve. *Running back [[Earnest Graham]] was placed on injured reserve after suffering a torn [[Achilles tendon]] during the game against Chicago. *[[Gerald McCoy]] was placed in injured reserve with an arm injury (November 7) ===Selected staff and personnel=== *Head coach [[Raheem Morris]] - Club exercised two-year contract extension *General manager [[Mark Dominik]] - Four-year contract extension *[[Pat Morris (American football)|Pat Morris]] named offensive line coach. *[[Keith Millard]] named defensive line coach. *[[Grady Stretz]] named defensive line coach. ==Preseason== ===Schedule=== The Buccaneers' preseason schedule was announced on April 12, 2011. For the third consecutive year, [[National Football League Training Camp|training camp]] was held at the team's facilities at One Buc Place. During training camp, Tampa Bay became the first NFL club to discontinue the use of paper copies of playbooks, and instead distributed all players their playbook and videos in electronic format via an [[iPad 2]].{{cite news |url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/football/bucs/article1187879.ece |title=Tampa Bay Buccaneers buy each player an iPad to hold playbook, videos |publisher=TampaBay.com |first=Rick |last=Stroud |date=2011-08-25 |accessdate=2011-08-25}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 92%;" "align=center" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week !! rowspan="2" | Date !! rowspan="2" | Kickoff !! rowspan="2" | Opponent !! colspan="2" | Results !! rowspan="2" | Game site !! rowspan="2" | TV !! rowspan="2" | NFL.com

4 |style="text-align:center;"| September 1 (Thurs.) |style="text-align:center;"| 7:30 p.m. EDT |style="text-align:center;"| at [[2011 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] |style="text-align:center;"| '''L''' 24â29 |style="text-align:center;"| 2â2 |style="text-align:center;"| [[FedEx Field]] |style="text-align:center;"| WTSP |style="text-align:center;"| [http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2011090159/2011/PRE4/buccaneers@redskins#menu=highlights&tab=recap Recap] |} *On March 21, 2011, [[Aqib Talib]] was arrested and charged with [[Aggravated assault|aggravated assault]] with a [[deadly weapon]] following an incident in [[Garland, Texas]], in which Talib and his mother allegedly shot at a man.{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=6599193 |title=Buccaneers' Aqib Talib indicted in Texas |publisher=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} On August 23, [[Aqib Talib|Talib]] met with NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] regarding possible game suspensions regarding his charge.{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/6893073/aqib-talib-tampa-bay-buccaneers-mum-discipline-talk-goodell |title=Aqib Talib quiet on meeting with NFL |publisher=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2011-08-24 |accessdate=2011-09-06}}{{cite news |url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/bucs/story/2011-08-24/talib-rejoins-bucs-after-meeting-goodell/50130658/1 |title=Talib rejoins Bucs after meeting NFL Commissioner Goodell |publisher=[[USA Today]] |date=2011-08-25 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} On August 27, it was announced that [[Aqib Talib|Talib]] would not be suspended for any games.{{cite news |url=http://www.wtsp.com/news/local/article/207852/8/No-suspension-for-Bucs-CB-Aqib-Talib |title=Bucs CB Aqib Talib avoids NFL suspension |publisher=[[WTSP]] |date=2011-08-27 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} ==Regular season== ===General summary=== After a somewhat surprising 10-6 campaign in [[2010 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|2010]], Tampa Bay had high hopes from 2011. A close loss to [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]] on opening day was followed by a three-game winning streak and a fairly strong 4-2 start with wins against division opponents [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]] and [[New Orleans Saints|New Orleans]]. However, self-inflicted troubles started affecting the season, leading to a five-game losing streak. Turnovers, penalties, and poor defense began taking its toll. Quarterback [[Josh Freeman]]'s uncharacteristic 16 interceptions through week 12 (second-worst in the league) was nearly triple his total from 2010. The once dominate Tampa Bay defense ranks 31st in the league. ===Schedule=== The Buccaneers' regular season schedule was announced April 19. Tampa Bay will play [[Chicago Bears|Chicago]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in [[London, England]] on October 23 as part of the [[NFL International Series]], with Tampa Bay serving as the host team. The team's [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers#Ring of Honor|Ring of Honor]] induction ceremony is scheduled to take place during the December 4 game against [[Carolina Panthers|Carolina]]. The team will honor [[Jimmie Giles]] at halftime, and wear their orange [[throwback uniforms]].{{cite news | url=http://www.buccaneers.com/news/article-1/Break-Out-the-Orange-Throwback-Game-Is-Dec-4/e112b5a8-4622-45cb-aa8d-9c72f3cb1ff5 | title=Break Out the Orange! J. Biggers]] - 7 tackles }} Tampa Bay led [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]] 16-13 with 1:49 remaining. The Buccaneers faced 4th down & 1 at the Atlanta 44 yard line. The Falcons had no timeouts remaining, and were looking to get the ball back for one last drive. [[Josh Freeman]] and the Buccaneers lined up for the fourth down play, and the Falcons flinched on the hard count. The Falcons were penalized 5 yards for ''Offsides'', the Buccaneers received a first down, and were able to run the clock out the secure the victory. Tampa Bay snapped a 5-game losing streak to their division rivals, and coach [[Raheem Morris]] won his first game against [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]]. ====Week 4: vs. Indianapolis Colts==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Four: Indianapolis Colts at Tampa Bay Buccaneers â Game summary |date=Monday October 3 |time=8:30 p.m. EDT |road=Colts |R1=3|R2=7|R3=7|R4=0 |home='''Buccaneers''' |H1=0|H2=7|H3=10|H4=7 |stadium=Raymond James Stadium, Tampa, Florida |attendance=63,972 |weather=80Â° F, Clear |referee=[[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Jon Gruden]] and [[Wendi Nix]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55227/TB_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *IND - 4 receptions, 59 yards * TB â [[Preston Parker]] - 4 receptions, 70 yards, 1 touchdown ;Top tacklers * IND â Conner - 14 tackles, 4 assists * TB â [[Gerald McCoy]] - 5 tackles, 1 assist, 1 sack }} Tampa Bay hosted the winless [[Indianapolis Colts]] on [[Monday Night Football]]. Miscues and penalties nearly cost the Buccaneers control of the game, but [[Josh Freeman]] threw for 287 yards, and [[LeGarrette Blount]] rushed for 127 yards, as Tampa Bay won the game 24-17. [[Curtis Painter]] started at quarterback for the Colts, his first career NFL start. The Colts led early after an [[Adam Vinatieri]] field goal. Tampa Bay then sacked [[Curtis Painter|Painter]] and recovered the fumble. [[Connor Barth]]'s field goal attempt, however, bounced off the upright, and the score remained 3-0. Late in the first quarter, [[Josh Freeman|Freeman]] connected to [[Arrelious Benn]], who ran 62 yards for an apparent touchdown. However, the touchdown was nullified since Benn has stepped out-of-bounds before the catch (illegal touching). In the second quarter, the Buccaneers pinned the Colts at their own 2 yard line. [[Curtis Painter|Painter]] threw to [[Pierre GarÃ§on]], who ran for an 87-yard touchdown, and 10-0 lead. Tampa Bay answered with a touchdown, and trimmed the score to 10-7. In the final seconds of the first half, [[Josh Freeman|Freeman]] drove the Buccaneers to the Colts 19 yard line, but was sacked with 20 seconds to go and counting. The field goal unit hurried on to the field, and the field goal was initially good. Tampa Bay, however, was penalized for 12 men on the field, and the score was nullified. Tied 17-17 in the fourth quarter, Tampa Bay received a punt with just under 7 minutes remaining. [[LeGarrette Blount]] blasted for a 35-yard touchdown run, and a 24-17 Tampa Bay lead. In the final three minutes, Tampa Bay ran out the clock, including a "4th & Inches" quarterback sneak by [[Josh Freeman|Freeman]], to seal the victory. This was Tampa Bay's first appearance on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' since 2008, and the first home Monday night game since 2003. This ''MNF'' telecast was notable in that [[Hank Williams, Jr.]]'s "[[All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight|All My Rowdy Friends]]" opening was omitted due to comments he made on ''[[Fox & Friends]]'' earlier in the day where he compared a golf outing involving [[Barack Obama]], [[John Boehner]], [[Joe Biden]], and [[John Kasich]] to "[[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] playing golf with [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]]."{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/04/showbiz/williams-football/ |title=Hank Williams Jr. apologizes for Hitler-Obama comparison |publisher=[[CNN|CNN.com]] 6 tackles, 1 assist }} [[Josh Freeman]] threw for 303 yards and two touchdown passes, as Tampa Bay rebounded from the previous week, and beat divisional rival [[New Orleans Saints|New Orleans]] by a score of 26-20. [[Drew Brees]] threw three interceptions, and the Saints lost a fumble, and Tampa Bay scored 10 points off of turnovers. Trailing 26-20 midway through the fourth quarter, [[Drew Brees|Brees]] drove the Saints to the Tampa Bay 4 yard line. On 4th down & 2 with 3:24 remaining, Drees was intercepted in the endzone by [[Quincy Black]]. The Buccaneers ran out the clock, and preserved the win. ====Week 7: vs. Chicago Bears==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Seven: Chicago Bears at Tampa Bay Buccaneers â Game summary |date=October 23 |time=5:00 p.m. [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]]/1:00 p.m. EDT |road='''Bears''' |R1=7|R2=7|R3=7|R4=3 |home=Buccaneers |H1=2|H2=3|H3=0|H4=13 |stadium=[[Wembley Stadium]], [[London, England]] ([[NFL International Series]]) |attendance=76,981 |weather=62Â° F, Clear |referee=[[Tony Corrente]] |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Kenny Albert]], [[Daryl Johnston]], [[Tony Siragusa]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55259/TB_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *Chi - 6 tackles, 1 assist }} Tampa Bay hosted [[Chicago Bears|Chicago]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in [[London, England]], their second time participating in the [[NFL International Series]]. [[Josh Freeman]] threw four interceptions, and Tampa Bay lost one fumble for five total turnovers. Chicago stretched out to a 21-5 lead before the Buccaneers staged a rally in the fourth quarter. [[Josh Freeman|Freeman]] threw two touchdown passes and the deficit was trimmed to 24-18 in the final two minutes. Freeman drove the Buccaneers to the Chicago 39 yard line, but the comeback was thwarted when he was intercepted with 37 seconds left. Running back [[LeGarrette Blount]] was inactive due to injury, and [[Earnest Graham]] left the game in the first quarter due to an ankle injury. Third-string running back [[Kregg Lumpkin]] was left to handle rushing duties, but managed only 15 yards. ====Week 9: at New Orleans Saints==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Nine: Tampa Bay Buccaneers at New Orleans Saints â Game summary |date=November 6 |time=1:00 p.m. EST/12:00 p.m. CST |road=Buccaneers |R1=0|R2=3|R3=3|R4=10 |home='''Saints''' |H1=7|H2=10|H3=7|H4=3 |stadium=[[Mercedes-Benz Superdome]], [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] |attendance=73,043 |weather=Played indoors (dome stadium) |referee=[[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Dick Stockton]] and [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55285/NO_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *NO - However, Tampa Bay tried to rally in the fourth quarter. [[Josh Freeman]] threw a touchdown pass to [[Kellen Winslow II|Kellen Winslow]] with 5:33 to go. The Saints, however, were able to run out the clock, and kicked a game-icing field goal to win 27-16. ====Week 10: vs. Houston Texans==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Ten: Houston Texans at Tampa Bay Buccaneers â Game summary |date=November 13 |time=1:00 p.m. EST |road='''Texans''' |R1=9|R2=7|R3=14|R4=7 |home=Buccaneers |H1=0|H2=3|H3=0|H4=6 |stadium=Raymond James Stadium, Tampa, Florida |attendance=56,037 |weather=77Â° F, Partly Cloudy |referee=[[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Marv Albert]] and [[Rich Gannon]] (blacked out locally) |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55305/TB_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *Hou - 8 tackles, 1 sack * TB â [[Adam Hayward]] - 7 tackles, 1 assist }} Tampa Bay lost their fourth game out of the last five, falling to [[Houston Texans|Houston]] by the score of 37-9. On the first play of the game, [[Matt Schaub]] completed a pass to [[Jacoby Jones]], who proceeded to go for an 80-yard touchdown. In the second quarter, [[Arian Foster]] had a 78-yard touchdown reception from Schaub, and the Texans were in control of the game throughout. [[Josh Freeman]] threw three interceptions, two of which led to touchdowns for Houston. ====Week 11: at Green Bay Packers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Eleven: Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Green Bay Packers â Game summary |date=November 20 |time=1:00 p.m. EST/12:00 p.m. CST |road=Buccaneers |R1=0|R2=10|R3=3|R4=13 |home='''Packers''' |H1=7|H2=14|H3=0|H4=14 |stadium=[[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |attendance=70,498 |weather=32Â° F, Cloudy |referee=[[Alberto Riveron]] |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Joe Buck]], [[Troy Aikman]] and [[Pam Oliver]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55315/GB_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *GB - [[B. With 4:25 remaining Tampa Bay scored a touchdown to trim the deficit to 28-26. An [[Onside kick|onside kick]] failed, and Green Bay took over. Green Bay iced the game with a touchdown with 2:55 to go. Undefeated Green Bay improved to 10-0 on the season, and avoided the scare by the Buccaneers. Tampa Bay dropped to 4-6. ====Week 12: at Tennessee Titans==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= {{NFLPrimaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|Tampa Bay Buccaneers}};text-align:center; |state=autocollapse |title= Week Twelve: Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Tennessee Titans â Game summary |date=November 27 |time=1:00 p.m. EST/12:00 p.m. CST |road=Buccaneers |R1=3|R2=7|R3=7|R4=0 |home='''Titans''' |H1=7|H2=3|H3=0|H4=13 |stadium=[[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |attendance=69,143 |weather=47Â° F, Cloudy |referee=[[Bill Leavy]] |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=Dick Stockton, John Lynch and [[Jennifer Hale (sportscaster)|Jennifer Hale]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/55333/TEN_Gamebook.pdf Gamebook] |scoring= ;First quarter *TB - 5 receptions, 51 yards ;Top tacklers * TB â [[Ronde Barber]] - 6 tackles, 1 assist * TEN â [[Colin McCarthy]] - 7 tackles, 3 assists }} Tampa Bay and [[Tennessee Titans|Tennessee]] combined for 9 penalties on a rainy, sloppy afternoon. [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] ran for 190 yards, but Tampa Bay led 17-10 late in the fourth quarter. Trailing 23-17, [[Josh Freeman]] drove Tampa Bay to the Tennessee 25 yard line in the final minute. Facing a 4th down and 1, Freeman tried a [[Quarterback sneak|QB sneak]], but fumbled the snap due to the wet ball. He was tackled for a loss, the Buccaneers turned the ball over on downs, and the Titans held on to win. ====Week 13: vs. Carolina Panthers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle= ==Television blackouts== ===Preseason=== Both of Tampa Bay's home [[National Football League preseason|preseason]] games were [[Blackout (broadcasting)|blacked out]] on local television because they failed to sell out prior to 72 hours before kickoff.{{cite news |url=http://www.baynews9.com/article/sports/2011/august/295348/Bucs-game-against-Patriots-to-be-blacked-out |title=Bucs game against Patriots will be blacked out |publisher=Bright House Sports Network |last=Deggans |date=2011-08-15 |accessdate=2011-08-22}}{{cite news |url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/media/content/amid-tampa-bay-buccaneers-blackout-wtsp-ch-10-air-tape-delayed-thursday-preseason-game-three |title=Amid Tampa Bay Buccaneers blackout, WTSP-Ch. 10 to air tape-delayed Thursday preseason game three times |publisher=TampaBay.com |work=The Feed |first=Eric |last=Deggans |date=2011-08-17 |accessdate=2011-08-22}}{{cite news |url=http://www2.tbo.com/sports/sports/2011/aug/15/5/bucs-preseason-games-against-patriots-dolphins-bla-ar-250643/ |title=Bucs preseason games against Patriots, Dolphins blacked out |publisher=TBO.com |work=Sports |first=Ira |last=Kaufman |date=2011-08-15 |accessdate=2011-08-22}} The affiliates affected include [[WTSP]] in the [[Tampa Bay Area|Tampa/St. Pete market]], [[WFTV]] in the [[Greater Orlando|Orlando market]] and [[WFTX-TV|WFTX]] in [[Southwest Florida|the Fort Myers area]]. The game was shown instead in [[Broadcast delay|tape delay]]. The game was aired live on [[WTLH]] in [[Tallahassee]] since it falls outside the designated 75-mile blackout radius. Dating back to [[2010 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|2010]], Tampa Bay has had four consecutive preseason home games blacked out. ===Regular season=== Tampa Bay's week 1 game against [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]]{{cite news |url=http://www2.tbo.com/news/breaking-news/2011/sep/09/bucs-blues-only-team-in-nfl-to-open-season-with-bl-ar-256472/ |title=Bucs' blues: Only team in NFL to open season with blackout |publisher=TBO.com |date=2011-09-09 |accessdate=2011-09-12}} and week 3 game against [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]]{{cite news |url=http://www.myfoxtampabay.com/dpp/sports/nfl/buccaneers/bucs-blacked-out-again |title=Bucs fans fed up with blackouts |publisher=[[WTVT|my FOX Tampa Bay]] |date=2011-09-25 |accessdate=2011-09-27}} failed to sell out, and were blacked out locally. Tampa Bay was the only NFL team to face a blackout in week 1. The [[NFL on Fox|FOX]] affiliates affected were [[WTVT]] in the [[Tampa Bay Area|Tampa/St. Pete market]] and [[WOFL]] in [[Greater Orlando|Orlando]]. Dating back to [[2010 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|2010]], Tampa Bay had ten consecutive regular season home games blacked out. The blackout streak ended in week 4, when the Buccaneers hosted the [[Indianapolis Colts|Colts]] on [[Monday Night Football]].{{cite news |url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/baseball/rays/sold-out-and-on-national-tv-rays-and-bucs-light-up-monday-night/1194912 |title=Sold out and on national TV, Rays and Bucs light up Monday night |publisher=TBO.com |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |first=Gary |last=Shelton |date=2011-10-03 |accessdate=2011-10-03}} The game was carried live on [[ESPN]] and simulcast on [[WFTS-TV|WFTS]]. The week 6 game against [[New Orleans Saints|New Orleans]] was blackout out.{{cite news |url=http://www2.tbo.com/sports/breaking-news/2011/oct/13/5/bucs-game-against-saints-will-be-blacked-out-ar-271804/ |title=Bucs-Saints game will be blacked out |publisher=TBO.com |work=[[The Tampa Tribune]] |first=Anwar |last=Richardson |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-19}} Tampa Bay's week 7 game against [[Chicago Bears|Chicago]] in [[London]] was not subject to blackout, regardless of sellout status.{{cite news |url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/qampa-theres-no-blackout-rule-for-bucs-home-game-in-england/1196125 |title=Sold out and on national TV, Rays and Bucs light up Monday night |publisher=TBO.com |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-11}} The week 10 game against the [[Houston Texans|Texans]] was also blacked out, affecting [[WTSP]] and [[WKMG-TV|WKMG]]. The final scheduled home game of the season against [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] on December 17 sold out, and will be aired locally on [[NFL Network]] and simulcast on [[WTTA]].{{cite news |url=http://www2.tbo.com/sports/bucs/2011/nov/08/8/bucs-home-game-against-cowboys-sells-out-ar-301615/ |title=Sold-out Bucs-Cowboys game will air on WTTA locally |publisher=TBO.com |work=[[The Tampa Tribune]] |first=Roy |last=Cummings |date=2011-11-08 |accessdate=2011-11-10}} ==External links== *[http://www.buccaneers.com Buccaneers.com â Official site] *[http://www.pewterreport.com/ Pewter Report] *[http://www.bucpower.com/ BUCPOWER] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Tampa Bay Buccaneers}} {{Tampa Bay Buccaneers seasons}} {{2011 NFL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2011 Tampa Bay Buccaneers Season}} [[Category:2011 National Football League season|Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] [[Category:Tampa Bay Buccaneers seasons|2011]]
